newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - UK's Railtrack sets 15 bln stg revamp.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - UK's Railtrack sets 15 bln stg revamp.

text.p: British railway infrastructure company Railtrack Group Plc unveiled a more than 15 billion pound ($24.2 billion) spending plan on Thursday aimed at creating one of the world's most efficient rail networks.
Railtrack, floated on the London Stock Exchange last year, said it would invest 8.3 billion pounds on renewal investments over 10 years.
It said it would spend 5.7 billion pounds on day-to-day maintenance and another 1.9 billion stg on network enhancement over the same period.
"We have a duty to spend these large sums wisely," said Robert Horton, Railtrack's chairman.
The company is under pressure to expedite its capital expenditure with watchdog, the Office of Rail Regulator, accusing it of not spending enough on maintenance.
Horton said the spending plans marked "a new dynamic phase in the regeneration of the nation's railway system."
"Ten years from now Britain will have a railway that is second to none -- both in the quality of its infrastructure and in the dependability of its train service," Horton said.
This was the first time Railtrack had announced such detailed plans since its 1.93 billion pound flotation last year.
"Now that the flotation is complete, Railtrack is free to commit all its energies to providing tangible benefits for its customers....freight operators," the chairman said.
Railtrack is also aiming to complete a 760 million pound upgrade of its stations and depots by 2001, including clearing the backlog of maintenance and renewals at 2,360 stations and 87 depots.
Railtrack has kept a provision of 1.4 billion pounds for modernising the West Coast Main Line.
The Office of the Rail Regulator said it was not yet ready to comment on the blueprint, but an official said it would have a strategy "to monitor" the actual implementation of Railtrack's plans.

The Office said Railtrack's backlog on capital expenditure had piled up to 330 million pounds from 270 million. It said Railtrack had only spent 20 million pounds out of a 450 million provision for 1996/97.
The Office was also recently joined by the UK opposition Labour Party which demanded Railtrack to be more accountable on investment commitments.
'Save our Railways' a pressure group, said the blueprint still implied that Britain spent "far less" on rail network than the French and Germans.
Horton played down the criticism in a BBC Radio interview broadcast immediately after the announcement saying "we spent every penny we were allowed to."
He did agree that many stations dotting Britain's landscape were "falling apart." ($ = 0.620 British Pounds)
